Entries.default: "Pallegina, doesn't it ever just feel... heavy to you?"
"Cuè? My armor?"
"No, the weight on your soul. Don't you worry one day it'll drag you to the depths of Hel? I know I do."
"What I just can't figure is how anyone could treasure animancy over the grace of our divine's guiding hand."
"Because the mercy of kith is less capricious than the gods' 'guiding hands.'"
"Funny. That doesn't answer my question."
"It is pathetic how easily wounded your faith is."
"Curse Eothas for all of this."
"Say that about Gaun, and I'll wash your mouth out - with mud."
"None of us did anything to deserve a chime. Do not be naïve. It is hardly a gift."
"No. My soul is light. It will enter the Beyond when I die, like anyone else's."
"You're right. Every soul does go in, but not every soul gets to come back out."
"Instead of worrying over my soul, worry about why the gods threaten us with damnation."
"What do you reckon you did to earn Hylea's chime? 'Cause it sure wasn't from potential for this life."
"Destructive? Uncaring? That is what the gods are, all of them."
"He can't be Eothas 'cause he died... but at the same time, I never thought Gaun could be so..."
"No, I won't believe that. There's a reason for everything. Even if we can't see it."
"Sometimes... maybe... you've got to be hard to be kind."
"Still waiting for the 'kind' part."
"Aloth, can I ask you something?"
"Saying 'no' has never stopped anyone before..."
"It's just that, I tried talking with Edér, but I don't seem to be making any headway. He doesn't want to warm up to me."
"He doesn't fight at the front because he's good with a sword. He's just dense as a stone."
"He's not one for subtlety. Think of him as a big, happy dog."
"Maybe you're right."
"Well, you don't have to make it seem so hopeless..."
"Does it ever trouble you? Being so far removed from the rest of your order."
"Didn't take you for the romantic type, Serafen."
"What'd you do before you were a shiphunter?"
"You say your lamp nets you souls, aye? Mind if I be asking how?"
"So what happens if you dry out too much?"
"For what do you obey your harvest god with such devotion, friend Xoti?"
"Tekēhu, would you mind terribly if I touched your hair?"
"How'd you come by that scar on your brow, Aloth?"
"You going to call me heretical, too?"
"This? I found myself in a rather... perilous situation with a band of darguls."
"A tongue's got a use or four, lass, and I be a right master of each."
"Yeah, I'm going to pretend like I didn't just hear that."
"Rough times, lass. Would spare you the telling, less you be set on it."
"Aye? Don't those be the tools of the animancer's art?"
"Faith can do many a thing, Serafen. Add a little copper and adra, and a normal lantern can work miracles."
"Maybe. But I'm no animancer, that's for sure. I ain't out to play god. Only serve mine."
"If it is Ngati's desire that I stay moist, she will hasten the rain."
"What do you mean, why? Like there's an alternative?"
"Of course not! Only touch gently and they will return the favor."
"Huh. That's what Engwirth said when we were necking in the murkberries."
"The Huana gods are a jungle of choices, I say! If the fish displeases you, look to the bird."
"I reckon I can handle it."
"Crew I were with, they'd give me any job they thought like to kill me. I lived to prove them wrong."
"Can't live the good times unless you survive the bad. That what being a pirate's all about?"
"Aye, sure enough. Sides, lasses say the scars be adding distinction."
"Which is to say, he's not one for taking hints."
"Which is not as unkind as it sounds. To him, anyway."
"Darguls can be real nasty. You're lucky that's all you got to show for it."
"I certainly gave them worse... not to boast, of course."
"Of course not. I'm terribly sorry, I didn't mean to pry."
"I didn't mean to jump on you. I'm just... used to being called names."
"It's all right. I understand the feeling."
"I admire you, Xoti. For holding to your beliefs, even against the wishes of your superiors."
"You really mean that? 'Cause I thought you didn't much like me."
"I mean it. It took me... entirely too long to learn to do the same."
"Been having some disturbing dreams. Makes it hard to sleep..."
"We're awake right now, aren't we?"
"Oh. Now I've dreamed of this place."
Sweating, Xoti sways on her feet.
"Don't worry. The vision's passed."
"I've been dreaming about a priest that died then rose again. What'd you think that means?"
"I see him walking Eora. Nothing but bones, lit by the flames of his soul."
"Did I tell you? You were in my dreams last night, Watcher."
"You were on your knees. Before my god. And I couldn't stop screaming."
"Death can be a beautiful thing, don't you think, Watcher?"
"Lately, all my dreams are washed in blood."
"I got a hunger in me. What I need is a soul for my lantern."
"Careful. Would hate for you to catch your death."
"That corpse is pretty as a painting. Look. Don't you see her?"
"I'm feeling weak in my bones, my mind, my blood, Watcher. What I need is to harvest a soul."
"You ever hear music in your mind? Like a chorus of screams. It's down right lovely."
"I see a corpse when I look at you. Worms wriggling out of your skin. But I know it ain't real, cause you don't smell of death yet."
"Last night, I sliced you to red ribbons. Guess it was a dream, cause here you stand."
